column4: and with the full command of her fortune—though her fortune bore no proportion to the family-estate—was not to be dissuaded from the marriage
column6: to the infinite mortification of Mr. and Mrs. Churchill
column7: who threw her off with due decorum. It was an unsuitable connection
column8: and did not produce much happiness. Mrs. Weston ought to have found more in it
column9: for she had a husband whose warm heart and sweet temper made him think every thing due to her in return for the great goodness of being in love with him; but though she had one sort of spirit
column10: she had not the best. She had resolution enough to pursue her own will in spite of her brother
column11: but not enough to refrain from unreasonable regrets at that brother's unreasonable anger
column12: nor from missing the luxuries of her former home. They lived beyond their income
column13: but still it was nothing in comparison of Enscombe: she did not cease to love her husband
column14: but she wanted at once to be the wife of Captain Weston
